author: Rebecca Sullivan
title: World’s first chocolate walk-through garden launches in Westfield Marion Adelaide |
text:
CHOCAHOLICS rejoice.
The world’s first chocolate walk-through garden, featuring 322 kilos of Lindt balls and a 200 litre chocolate pond, has launched at Westfield Marion in Adelaide.
The Willy Wonka-esque wonderland took more than 243 hours to create and looks like a veggie garden — including celery, cauliflower, pumpkins, mushrooms, carrots, a scarecrow and gardening tools — all made from chocolate.
15kg of chocolate gravel was used to create this flower garden. Source: Supplied
The garden is made up of 300 Lindt chocolate blocks, 15 kilos of chocolate gravel, 47 kilos of flavoured chocolate, 215 kilos of milk chocolate and 152 kilos of dark chocolate. More than 100 litre of liquid chocolate has been used to paint the walls and floor.
The shopping centre’s air conditioning is set at 22 degrees, so the chocolate doesn’t melt.
The chocolate garden was designed by gardening expert and Gardening Australia presenter Sophie Thomson, along with Bracegirdle and Edible Blooms .
The chocolate veggie patch. Source: Supplied
“It’s like something out of Dr Seuss, really,” Ms Thomson told news.com.au. “You wouldn’t be able to tell that the celery and carrots are made from chocolate.
“One of my favourite parts of the garden is the rainbow tree. It has seven main branches all painted different colours and on each branch are balls of chocolate.
“Each branch has its own colour and is on a turntable, so it spins around slowly,” she said.
Around 322kg of mint-flavoured Lindt balls have been used in the garden. Source: Supplied
Ms Thomson says it has been incredibly rewarding to work on such a worthwhile project.
“Just seeing little kids going through it and their eyes go wide, and the smell is amazing. The whole thing has been lots of fun and a wonderful opportunity to raise money for charity,” she said.
While you can’t eat any of the display, there are chocolates available to purchase at the event. Visitors can also enter a competition to win a giant piece of the garden to take home and eat.
The chocolate garden is open from 10.30am to 5pm and it will be un Westfield Marion until Tuesday 6th October.
Some of the chocolate creations from Edible Blooms. Source: Supplied
